conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph and calculate the displacement of the particle over the given time interval.
The graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time.
The area under the v-t graph represents the displacement of the particle.

premise: From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
conclusion: Displacement from 0 to 1 second = velocity × time = 2 m/s × 1 s = 2 meters.

premise: From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.
conclusion: Displacement from 1 to 2 seconds = 0.5 × base × height = 0.5 × 1 s × 2 m/s = 1 meter.

premise: From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
conclusion: Displacement from 2 to 3 seconds = 0.5 × base × height = 0.5 × 1 s × (-2 m/s) = -1 meter.

premise: Total displacement = displacement from 0 to 1 s + displacement from 1 to 2 s + displacement from 2 to 3 s
conclusion: Total displacement = 2 meters + 1 meter - 1 meter = 2 meters.

premise: The total displacement from 0 to 3 seconds is 2 meters.
conclusion: Since the displacement is not zero, the particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
